726333f-a.title: Queens: College Place - 9th Road
726333f-a.text:
College Place, west side, at 9th Road, showing an old
private wansion. The owner, in 1873, was Hugo Funke, and in
1891 and 1909 A. L. and A. H. Popenhausen, respectively.
P. L. Sperr  March 16, 1932
NO REPRODUCTIONS

726332f-a.title: Queens: College Place - 9th Road
726332f-a.text:
The Poppenhusen Institute
P H I L A N T H E O P I S T :Sa lover of mankind; one who
sympathizes with and endeavors to help his fellow men. -fddctionaty.)
Cne wwho fully deserved the term, but received little recognition
beyond his immediate locale for his gifts, was Conrad Poppenhusen
of College Point.
A German immigrant, arriving in America in 1843, he soon made
a fortune, lost it, and then made another.
Poppenhusen's early business training was ac uired in Germany,
where his father owned a concern that manufectured numerous stnall
articles out of whalebone. Upon his arrival in America, with
considerable means, he went into a partnership and continued the
same type of manufacture. Thalebone was becomming a Scarce comtmodity
at about this timue and when Conrad made the ac uaintance of
Charles Goodyear he turned his attention to thb development of
rubber. Not a scientist by any aeans, but a good businessman,
Possenhusen eventually established a factory in College Point,
manufacturing conbs and other small artioles out of hard rubber.
We might say that hard rubber articles were the plastics of one
hundred years ago.
In 1898 several of the hard rubber firms were consolidated and
became the American Hard Rubber Company, still in existence and
still in College Point.
ifter attaining marked financial success through his application
to business, he turned that success to the lasting benefit of the
community. He took a deep interest in many fields, such as town
planning, broviding homes for his employees in whose welfare he
took a personal interest, and other aid projects. At one time he gave
330,000 for the building of the College Point Dutch Reformed
Church and in celebration of his 50th birthday he made a gift of
one hundred thousand dollars to the people of College Point
for the erection and maintenance of what became the Poppenhusen
Institute, designed a century ago to provide free instruction
in the Arts and Crafts and also commercial and industrial subjects.
College Point gets its name from the fact that the Rev. W. A.
Kuhlenberg founded St. Paul's College there in 1835. The college
is long slnce gone but the community holds it nanue; College Point.
The institute, built in 1868, dominates the landscape above the factor
near the homes of his workers and played a mostimportant role in
the life of the community. It served as a bank, school, town
office, library, Jail, and youth center.. Th building expresses
the tastes of the times between 1854 and 1880.
A historical room has recently been undertaken, and here, may be seen
any old maps, photographs, and anti;ues of the past, and attempts
to recreate the town of the past, to revive the flavor of life a
century ago.
